title: Lesson 52 - Same, Similar, As, Like This; Pareho, Kasing, Parang, Ganito

vocabulary.english: like that (adj); in that way (adv) (near listener)
like that (adj); in that way (adv) (far from both speaker and listener)

contents.markdown: Just like in English, there are many ways to say items are the same or similar in Tagalog. In this lesson we will cover some of the most colloquial ones.
As an adjective, _pareho_ roughly means “the same”.

item.english: We like the same car.
We (incl.) are not the same.
They are looking out for the same man.

contents.markdown: As an adverb used before an adjective, _pareho_ roughly means “both”.

item.tagalog: Parehong masaya ang aso at pusa.
item.english: The cat and dog are both happy.
Those are both cheap.

contents.markdown: Notice that _pareho_ is a host when placed before an adjective.

item.tagalog: Hindi ko alam, kasi pareho silang maganda.
item.english: I do not know, because they are both pretty.

contents.markdown: _Kasing_ is an adverb that modifies adjectives to roughly mean “as adjective as”.
Kasing + **adj root** + noun1+ noun2. (Tag.) = Noun 1 is as adjective as noun2. (Eng.)
**Note: Noun1 takes _ng_ form; noun2 takes _ang_ form.**

item.tagalog: Kasing ganda rin ni Angel si Maria.
item.english: Maria is also as beautiful as Angel.

item.tagalog: Hindi po kasing init ng sasakyan ang pagkain.
item.english: The food is not as hot as the car. (resp.)

item.tagalog: Kasing mura ng mangga ang halo-halong inilagay ko sa lamesa.
item.english: The halo-halo that I put on the table is as cheap as the mango.

contents.markdown: As an adjective, _parang_ is used before nouns to roughly mean “similar to” or “like”.

item.english: Maria is like Jasmine.

item.tagalog: Hindi parang pizza ang pagkaing binili niya.
item.english: The food he bought is not similar to pizza.
That lady is like a teacher.

contents.markdown: As an adverb, _parang_ is used before adjectives and verbs to roughly mean “seems” or “it seems like”.

item.tagalog: Parang gumawa si David ng halo-halo.
item.english: It seems like David made halo-halo.
It seems she is not tired.

item.tagalog: Parang ibibigay mo ang pera kay Joe.
item.english: It looks like you will give the money to Joe.

contents.markdown: _Tulad_(adj), _gaya_(adj) and _mukha_(adv) are fairly commonly used words that can have the same meanings as _parang_:

item.english: Maria is like Jasmine.

item.tagalog: Hindi gaya ng pizza ang pagkaing binili niya.
item.english: The food he bought is not similar to pizza.

item.tagalog: Mukhang gumawa si David ng halo-halo.
item.english: It seems like David made halo-halo.

contents.markdown: But they are not as common as _parang_, so we will not use them any further.

_Ganito/ganun_ can be used as adjectives or adverbs. As adjectives they mean “like this/that”, and as adverbs they mean “in this/that way”. Note that in this book, for the same reasons listed for _iyan/iyon_, we have reduced _ganiyan/ganoon_ to _ganun_.

item.english: She is like this.
It grew in that way.

item.tagalog: Hindi ko alam na magiging ganito.
item.english: I did not know it would be like this.
Is she that tired?
The car is not that fast.
They are this poor.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Kailangang mamili ang parehong babae ng mga murang bagay.
exampleSentences.english: The same woman has to shop for cheap things.
We (excl.) were as happy as the one who acquired the job.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Parang igagawa ba ni David non ang sarili niya?
exampleSentences.english: Does it seem like David will make that for himself?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Ganito rin ang meron siya sa bahay niya nung ikasiyam ng Disyembre.
exampleSentences.english: The one he had at his house on the 9th of December was like this too.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Sinabi ni Jessicang hindi ganun kainit sa Seattle.
exampleSentences.english: Jessica said that it was not that hot in Seattle.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Parehong nakakainis ang mga babaeng namamasyal sa kalsada
exampleSentences.english: The women taking a walk in the street are both annoying..

exampleSentences.tagalog: Hindi po kasing sarap ng mangga ang halo-halo.
exampleSentences.english: The halo-halo is not as delicious as the mango. (resp.)

exampleSentences.tagalog: Parang bata ang lalaking nagkaroon ng walong aso.
exampleSentences.english: The man who had eight dogs is like a kid.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Naniniwala akong hindi ganito kabilis ang sasakyan.
exampleSentences.english: I believe that the car is not this fast.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Wala akong masabi kapag nangyayari ito nang ganun.
exampleSentences.english: I have nothing to say when it happens like that.
